TITLE: A lawsuit picks a bone with Buffalo Wild Wings: Are 'boneless wings' really wings?
SUMMARY: The "boneless wings" served by Buffalo Wild Wings, the national chain of casual sports bar-restaurants, have long been made of white meat from boneless chicken breasts.

TITLE: Jiang Yanyong, the doctor who exposed the size of the 2003 SARS outbreak, dies at 91
SUMMARY: Jiang Yanyong was a Chinese military doctor who revealed the full extent of the 2003 SARS outbreak and was later placed under house arrest for his political outspokenness.

TITLE: Maternal deaths in the U.S. spiked in 2021, CDC reports
SUMMARY: After years of high rates, the country hit a new high during the pandemic, far exceeding rates in other developed nations. Black women are at especially high risk.

TITLE: Bobby Caldwell, singer of 'What You Won't Do for Love,' dies at 71
SUMMARY: Bobby Caldwell's smooth soul jam "What You Won't Do for Love" went to No. 9 on the Billboard Hot 100. It became a long-term standard and career-defining hit for Caldwell, who also wrote the song.

TITLE: The truth is there's little the government can do about lies on cable
SUMMARY: Tucker Carlson trying to rewrite history on the Jan. 6 riots is exposing the government's limited ability to regulate distortions on cable news.

TITLE: Sickle cell patient's success with gene editing raises hopes and questions
SUMMARY: A Mississippi woman's life has been transformed by a treatment for sickle cell disease with the gene-editing technique CRISPR. All her symptoms from a disease once thought incurable have disappeared.

TITLE: 'Heart Sutra' is a satire that skewers religious institutions without mocking faith
SUMMARY: Chinese novelist Yan Lianke treats the deities of China's major religions as quiet, omnipresent participants in the novel's events, which range from slapstick comedy to shocking violence.

TITLE: Credit Suisse shares soar after securing a $54 billion lifeline from Switzerland
SUMMARY: Shares of the Swiss banking giant rallied significantly Thursday after Switzerland's central bank agreed to lend it $54 billion.

TITLE: The U.S. military releases footage of Black Sea drone crash with Russian jet
SUMMARY: The 42-second video comes two days after the Pentagon accused a Russian aircraft of colliding with an uncrewed, MQ-9 surveillance drone. The Kremlin has denied it intentionally downed the vehicle.

TITLE: The U.S. is sending an ambassador to India after leaving the job vacant for 26 months
SUMMARY: It was the longest diplomatic gap in the history of U.S.- Indian relations, at a time when the two countries say they're closer than ever before

TITLE: French lawmakers vote on Macron's controversial plan to raise the retirement age
SUMMARY: The bill would raise the retirement age from 62 to 64 and heads toward a climax Thursday, either through a vote or a special presidential action, as protests and strikes roil the country.

TITLE: Mets' Edwin DÃ­az hurts his knee during a World Baseball Classic celebration
SUMMARY: New York Mets star closer Edwin DÃ­az injured his right knee celebrating a win that advanced Puerto Rico in the World Baseball Classic and eliminated the Dominican Republic.

TITLE: A train carrying corn syrup derails in Arizona
SUMMARY: About eight train cars went off the tracks Wednesday evening in Mohave County, Ariz., near the California border. The incident follows a recent string of high-profile train derailments.

TITLE: Macron shuns French parliament to push through unpopular plan to raise retirement age
SUMMARY: France's president pushed through the controversial bill via a special constitutional power. The move, which will raise the retirement age to 64 from 62, is expected to trigger a no-confidence motion.

TITLE: Credit Suisse shares soar after the bank secures a $54 billion lifeline
SUMMARY: Shares of the Swiss banking giant rallied significantly Thursday after Switzerland's central bank agreed to lend it $54 billion.

TITLE: Congress steps closer to formally repealing the resolutions authorizing the Iraq wars
SUMMARY: If the Senate approves a procedural vote Thursday to repeal authorization of the use of force in Iraq, a final vote in the chamber could come near the 20th anniversary of the U.S. invasion of Iraq.

TITLE: North Dakota Supreme Court ruling keeps the state's abortion ban on hold for now
SUMMARY: The state's high court ruled Thursday that a North Dakota abortion ban will remain blocked while a lawsuit over its constitutionality proceeds.

TITLE: The U.K. is the latest to ban TikTok on government phones because of security concerns
SUMMARY: British authorities said they are banning the Chinese-owned video-sharing app TikTok from government mobile phones following similar moves by the U.S. and European Union.

TITLE: Poland will send fighter jets to Ukraine, the first NATO country to do so
SUMMARY: Ukraine has long sought fighter jets, though these are old Soviet-made MiG-29s and not the more advanced Western warplanes that Kyiv covets.

TITLE: Macron imposes an unpopular plan to raise retirement age, shunning a vote by lawmakers
SUMMARY: France's president pushed through the controversial bill via a special constitutional power. The move, which will raise the retirement age to 64 from 62, is expected to trigger a no-confidence motion.

TITLE: Drag queen (and ordained minister) Bella DuBalle won't be silenced by new Tenn. law
SUMMARY: DuBalle says the legislators behind a new law criminalizing public drag shows don't understand the art: "They think that every drag performer is doing something hypersexual or obscene."

TITLE: Runaway goats in San Francisco were probably ... freaked out
SUMMARY: The video of goats dashing through the streets of San Francisco drew thousands of views on Twitter and was the subject of much joking. We asked a goat specialist to weigh in.

TITLE: Senate advances a bill to repeal Iraq war authorizations
SUMMARY: A bill to repeal authorization of the use of force in Iraq has cleared a procedural hurdle in the Senate. A final vote in the chamber could come near the 20th anniversary of the U.S. invasion of Iraq.

TITLE: 7 Virginia deputies face murder charges in a Black man's death at a mental hospital
SUMMARY: Irvo Otieno was transferred from jail to a state mental health facility on March 6. Prosecutors say he was handcuffed during the intake process and "smothered" by seven deputies for some 12 minutes.

TITLE: Macron puts his government at risk with decision to raise the retirement age in France
SUMMARY: France's president pushed through the controversial bill via a special constitutional power. The move, which will raise the retirement age to 64 from 62, is expected to trigger a no-confidence motion.

TITLE: First Republic Bank becomes the latest bank to be rescued, this time by its rivals
SUMMARY: The lenders including J.P.Morgan and Wells Fargo would deposit $30 billion into the beleaguered midsized lender as part of the rescue.

TITLE: Lawmakers are split on how to respond to the recent bank failures
SUMMARY: Days after the failure of two regional banks shook the financial industry, lawmakers say they want answers but disagree on what role Congress should play right now.

TITLE: 10 Virginia deputies face murder charges in a Black man's death at a mental hospital
SUMMARY: Irvo Otieno was transferred from jail to a state mental health facility on March 6. Prosecutors say he was handcuffed during the intake process and "smothered" by deputies for some 12 minutes.

TITLE: Child care demand outpaces supply. In rural U.S., there may be no supply
SUMMARY: For many families, its extremely difficult to find child care â especially in rural areas where the need far outweighs any available options.

TITLE: Yellen tries to reassure Americans that bank collapse fallout will be contained
SUMMARY: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says bank depositors can feel confident their money is safe.  Yellen promised a thorough review of what went wrong at two regional banks that failed in the past week.

TITLE: California storms are taking a toll on farmworkers like those in the town of Pajaro
SUMMARY: In the area, berry fields have become small lakes, leaving workers without jobs, food and, in some cases, housing.

TITLE: Activists spread misleading information to fight solar
SUMMARY: Citizens for Responsible Solar is part of a growing backlash against renewable energy in rural communities across the United States.

TITLE: Markey calls Biden's decision to back the Willow Project 'an environmental injustice'
SUMMARY: The Biden administration approved a major oil extraction project in Alaska, a decision that has divided Democrats. NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Sen. Ed Markey, who opposes the project.

TITLE: 7 deputies and 3 others face murder charges in a Black man's death at mental hospital
SUMMARY: Irvo Otieno was transferred from jail to a state mental health facility on March 6. Prosecutors say he was handcuffed during the intake process and "smothered" by seven deputies for some 12 minutes.

TITLE: How the slam dunk became this director's metaphor for the Asian American experience
SUMMARY: When is a dunk more than a dunk? When it's wrapped up in proving yourself to your entire high school.

TITLE: A $3.5 billion accounting error puts the South Carolina comptroller's job on the line
SUMMARY: State lawmakers angry over the accounting blunder by Comptroller General Richard Eckstrom began efforts to oust him, a day after demanding he quit or be fired. He has signaled he won't resign.

TITLE: Denver donates 35 bison to Native American tribes
SUMMARY: The transfers marked another example of Indigenous people reclaiming stewardship over the land and animals that their ancestors managed for thousands of years.

TITLE: First Republic becomes the latest bank to be rescued, this time by its rivals
SUMMARY: The lenders including J.P.Morgan and Wells Fargo would deposit $30 billion into the beleaguered midsized lender as part of the rescue.

TITLE: Jim Gordon, a famed session drummer who killed mother, dies
SUMMARY: Jim Gordon, the famed session drummer who backed Eric Clapton and The Beach Boys before being diagnosed with schizophrenia and going to prison for killing his mother, has died. He was 77.

TITLE: Trains derail in Arizona and Washington, with oil spilled on Puget Sound tribal land
SUMMARY: The derailment in Washington state occurred on a berm along Padilla Bay, on the Swinomish tribal reservation near Anacortes. Most of 5,000 gallons of spilled diesel fuel leaked on the land.

TITLE: New Zealand lawmakers banned from TikTok amid data use fears
SUMMARY: New Zealand lawmakers and other workers inside the nation's Parliament will be banned from having the TikTok app on their government phones, officials said Friday.

TITLE: Michigan Democrats are getting their way for the first time in nearly 40 years
SUMMARY: For the first time in decades, Democrats run the show in Michigan, passing legislative priorities they've been after for years: repealing a 1931 abortion law, repealing right-to-work and more.

TITLE: 'Poverty, By America' shows how the rest of us benefit by keeping others poor
SUMMARY: Pulitzer winner for <em>Evicted

TITLE: Volcanic activity on Venus spotted in radar images, scientists say
SUMMARY: Data from an old NASA spacecraft reveals a volcano erupted on the surface of Venus in 1991, a new study in Science says.

TITLE: Biden has big ideas for fixing child care. For now a small workaround will have to do
SUMMARY: The administration is turning to semiconductors in the hopes of expanding affordable child care.

TITLE: 'Back to one meal a day': SNAP benefits drop as food prices climb
SUMMARY: A lot of people don't think twice about buying milk, says Teresa Calderez. "But there are lots of us out here who can't buy a gallon of milk when we need it."

TITLE: Jim Gordon, a famed session drummer who was convicted of killing his mother, dies
SUMMARY: Jim Gordon, the famed session drummer who backed Eric Clapton and The Beach Boys before being diagnosed with schizophrenia and going to prison for killing his mother, has died. He was 77.

TITLE: China's leader Xi Jinping will meet with Russia's Vladimir Putin in Moscow next week
SUMMARY: Moscow said the long-anticipated visit is coming at the invitation of President Vladimir Putin. The talks are expected to focus on the war in Ukraine, though it wasn't mentioned explicitly.

TITLE: Russia awards pilots involved in confrontation with a U.S. drone over Black Sea
SUMMARY: The United States accused Russia of an "unsafe" and "unprofessional" intercept of its MQ-9 Reaper surveillance drone that forced it to be brought down over the Black Sea this week

TITLE: Robert Smith of The Cure convinces Ticketmaster to give partial refunds, lower fees
SUMMARY: The announcement came a day after Smith shared his frustrations with Ticketmaster, saying he was "as sickened as you all are" by the company's fees.

TITLE: Clinics on wheels bring doctors and dentists to health care deserts
SUMMARY: Health care vans that provided COVID testing and vaccines in the pandemic are now providing a range of health services in hard-to-reach communities. New access to federal funds could expand the trend.

TITLE: The third season of 'Ted Lasso' basks in the glow of its quirky characters
SUMMARY: Jason Sudeikis' Ted Lasso returns as folksy as ever, but one wonders if there is enough ah shucks personality to carry the series to a compelling end.

TITLE: Turkey says it will ratify Finland's bid to join NATO
SUMMARY: "NATO will become stronger with Finland's membership and thus, I believe, will play an active role in maintaining global security and stability," Turkey's president said Friday.

TITLE: The International Criminal Court issues an arrest warrant for Putin
SUMMARY: The ICC has issued warrants for the Russian president and his children's rights commissioner for alleged war crimes involving accusations that Russia has forcibly taken Ukrainian children.

TITLE: Biden wants Congress to boost penalties for executives when mid-sized banks fail
SUMMARY: President Biden said the current law limits his administration's power to hold executives responsible when mid-sized banks fail due to mismanagement.

TITLE: WHO calls on China to share data on raccoon dog link to pandemic. Here's what we know
SUMMARY: Data was released briefly, then rescinded. As NPR reported previously, there is already strong evidence pointing to these animals in the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in Wuhan.

TITLE: Ford recalls 1.5 million vehicles over problems with brake hoses and windshield wipers
SUMMARY: The automaker is recalling nearly 1.3 million 2013-2018 Ford Fusion and Lincoln MKZ sedans, as well as 220,000 F-150 pickups from 2021. Here's what to do if your vehicle might be affected.

TITLE: Cyclone Freddy shattered records. People lost everything. How does the healing begin?
SUMMARY: The countries hit by this unprecedented storm now must  help survivors who may have lost nearly everything. We talk to an aid worker on the ground in Mozambique for insights.

TITLE: What is Babesiosis? A rare tick-borne disease is on the rise in the Northeast
SUMMARY: Lyme Disease isn't the only tick-driven illness that residents of the northeast should worry about. The CDC says cases of Babesiosis, which can cause flu-like symptoms, are on the rise in 8 states.

TITLE: Judge to decide in April whether to delay prison for Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes
SUMMARY: Holmes was sentenced to 11 years in prison for defrauding investors out of more than $100 million. Now, she has asked a judge to remain free on bail until her appeal is heard.

TITLE: They performed with Bono and The Edge (after their parents told them who they are)
SUMMARY: Or perhaps Bono and The Edge performed with <em>them

TITLE: Read the transcript: What happened inside the federal hearing on abortion pills
SUMMARY: Read the transcript from Wednesday's hearing before Judge Matthew Kacsmaryk in a federal case that could decide the future of access to a major abortion pill.

TITLE: Ohio becomes latest Republican state to leave a key voting data partnership
SUMMARY: Six GOP-led states have now pulled out of the Electronic Registration Information Center, despite it being considered one of the best tools states have to detect voter fraud.

TITLE: Lance Reddick, star of 'John Wick' and 'The Wire,' dead at 60
SUMMARY: Reddick was found dead at his Los Angeles home Friday. He died of natural causes.

TITLE: Locals look for silver linings as Amazon hits pause on its new HQ
SUMMARY: Amazon's announcement of a pause in development of its second headquarters, in suburban Washington, D.C., is raising questions about the impact on the local economy.

TITLE: New Orleans Police Department taps civilians amid an officer shortage
SUMMARY: Many police departments accept they may never get the number of officers they used to have. The New Orleans PD is "retooling" for a new reality that includes handing some duties to civilians.

TITLE: After this week's bank failures, some encouraging signs, but worries persist
SUMMARY: A look back on the past week in banking news, explained.

TITLE: Here's what the latest version of ChatGPT gets right â and wrong
SUMMARY: Open AI released a new version of ChatGPT this week. It claims GPT-4 is more powerful than ever, and could even do your taxes. But a quick test drive revealed some problems.

TITLE: What to watch for after a volatile week on Wall Street
SUMMARY: Markets have been volatile since Silicon Valley Bank collapsed, amid fears of wider problems with the banking system. Days away from a critical Federal Reserve meeting, they're even more on edge.

TITLE: Recruiting troubles accelerate Army's plan to bring back 'Be All You Can Be'
SUMMARY: Faced with a recruiting crisis, the Army has dusted off one of its most popular slogans: "Be All You Can Be."  But will that prove popular with a new generation of potential recruits?

TITLE: Fairleigh Dickinson stuns top-seeded Purdue during March Madness
SUMMARY: Fairleigh Dickinson became the second No. 16 seed in history to win an NCAA Tournament game, thanks to a relentless, hustling defense.

TITLE: Wyoming's governor has signed a law prohibiting abortion pills
SUMMARY: Wyoming Gov. Mark Gordon signed a bill Friday night prohibiting abortion pills in the state and also allowed a separate measure restricting abortion to become law without his signature.

TITLE: Former Air Force officer gets prison term for Jan. 6 Capitol attack
SUMMARY: Larry Brock of Texas joined other rioters on the Senate floor only minutes after then-Vice President Mike Pence, senators and their staff fled to escape the mob attacking the building on Jan. 6, 2021.

TITLE: You have the right to a lawyer, but public defenders note a lack of resources, respect
SUMMARY: Public defenders operate under heavy pressure and budget constraints 60 years after the Supreme Court ruled low-income criminal defendants should be provided lawyers even if they can't pay for them.

TITLE: Why car prices are still so high â and why they are unlikely to fall anytime soon
SUMMARY: The average new vehicle costs nearly $49,000, an almost $10,000 increase from before the pandemic. This is a look at today's deeply weird auto market.

TITLE: Audubon faces a backlash after deciding to keep name that evokes a racist enslaver
SUMMARY: Three board members resigned after the National Audubon Society rejected calls to change its name. Some local groups are renaming themselves anyway.

TITLE: An infamous Russian unit that downed a civilian plane in 2014 was active in Ukraine
SUMMARY: A secretive Russian military unit, known for its part in the deaths of hundreds of civilians on Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 nearly a decade ago, was fighting in eastern Ukraine, NPR uncovered.

TITLE: San Francisco will discuss reparation proposals â but even supporters are split
SUMMARY: While many cheered the possibility of a huge financial windfall for the city's Black residents, one civil rights leader says the proposal is a distraction from tangible efforts to redress racism.

TITLE: Paris Hilton was the center of it all. Now she's shedding the 'character' she created
SUMMARY: Before the word "influencer" was a household term, before Instagram and TikTok allowed users to document every moment of their life in real time, Paris Hilton was the woman at the center of it all.

TITLE: Police didn't get defunded but many large departments are shrinking
SUMMARY: A new study finds that some police forces are losing officers at a faster pace since 2020. In New Orleans, there's a grudging acceptance that it's time to offload some duties to civilians.

TITLE: Military surgeon Jiang Yanyong, the doctor who spoke the truth about SARS
SUMMARY: In 2003, Dr. Jiang Yanyong watched in disbelief as Chinese officials downplayed how SARS was spreading in China. He took the risky step of alerting the media to the cover-up.

TITLE: Putin visits Crimea to mark the anniversary of its annexation from Ukraine
SUMMARY: Russian President Vladimir Putin traveled to the Black Sea peninsula to mark the ninth anniversary of its annexation from Ukraine. Russia's move in 2014 was denounced as illegal by most of the world.

TITLE: Trump claims that he will be arrested next week
SUMMARY: The claim comes as a New York prosecutor considers charging him in connection with hush money paid to adult film actress Stormy Daniels. There has been no announcement of plans for an indictment.

TITLE: My meeting with Jiang Yanyong, the Chinese doctor who dared speak the truth about SARS
SUMMARY: In 2003, the military surgeon watched in disbelief as Chinese officials downplayed how SARS was spreading â and took the risk of alerting the media to the cover-up. He died this past week at age 91.

TITLE: Raccoon dogs may have been linked to the pandemic. What are they?
SUMMARY: The wild animals are more similar to foxes than to domesticated dogs. Data that suggested a link between raccoon dogs and the origins of the COVID pandemic was removed from an international database.

TITLE: Russia agrees to extend the Ukraine grain deal again
SUMMARY: Brokered by the United Nations and Turkey, the deal allows Ukraine to ship food and fertilizer through a humanitarian corridor from Black Sea ports. The duration of the extension remained uncertain.

TITLE: Tejano musician Fito Olivares dies at 75
SUMMARY: The noted saxophonist, known for songs that were wedding and quinceaÃ±era mainstays including the hit "Juana La Cubana," died in Houston. He started playing professionally in his teens.

TITLE: A Florida professor says his contract was terminated for teaching about racial justice
SUMMARY: A longtime English professor at Palm Beach Atlantic University  says his "decision to teach and speak about racial justice" led to a parent complaining and the university terminating his contract.

TITLE: Frozen strawberries sold at Costco, Trader Joe's, recalled after hepatitis A outbreak
SUMMARY: Five people in Washington state got sick after eating frozen strawberries from the same supplier, federal regulatory investigators said. The FDA is urging people to stop eating certain products.

TITLE: Parliament-Funkadelic singer Clarence 'Fuzzy' Haskins dies at 81
SUMMARY: The influential vocalist played a key role in shaping the funk and R&B sound of the 1970s.

TITLE: A strong earthquake has killed at least 13 in Ecuador and 1 in Peru
SUMMARY: The U.S. Geological Survey reported a 6.8 magnitude earthquake centered just off the Pacific Coast, about 50 miles south of Guayaquil, Ecuador's second-largest city.

TITLE: Vladimir Putin has made a surprise visit to the occupied city of Mariupol
SUMMARY: Russian President Vladimir Putin has visited the port city of Mariupol, Russian state news agencies reported, in his first trip to Ukrainian territory that Moscow illegally annexed in September.

TITLE: 3 takeaways 20 years after the invasion of Iraq
SUMMARY: Two decades ago, then-President George W. Bush announced the start of combat operations in Iraq. The bloody occupation that followed lasted longer and cost more in lives and money than anyone guessed.

TITLE: Opioids are devastating Cherokee families. The tribe has a $100 million plan to heal
SUMMARY: The fentanyl crisis is hitting young people hard, and the highest death rates are in Native American communities. The Cherokee Nation is working to help young families recover.

TITLE: A strong earthquake has killed at least 15 in Ecuador and 1 in Peru
SUMMARY: The U.S. Geological Survey reported a 6.8 magnitude earthquake centered just off the Pacific Coast, about 50 miles south of Guayaquil, Ecuador's second-largest city.

TITLE: How do you take a picture of happiness? We asked photographers to surprise us
SUMMARY: Monday, March 20 is International Day of Happiness â as proclaimed by the United Nations. The themes this year are gratitude and kindness. We asked photographers to send us images in that vein.

TITLE: South Korea has the world's lowest fertility rate, a struggle with lessons for us all
SUMMARY: South Korea's government has moved aggressively to encourage more childbirth, but its ongoing struggles point to the complexity of a challenge that is only becoming more salient around the world.

TITLE: Bank fail: How rising interest rates paved the way for Silicon Valley Bank's collapse
SUMMARY: Silicon Valley Bank invested billions of dollars in super safe U.S. government bonds. But that choice exposed to the bank to a whole other set of risks.

TITLE: Trump claims that he will be arrested this week
SUMMARY: The claim comes as a New York prosecutor considers charging him in connection with hush money paid to adult film actress Stormy Daniels. There has been no announcement of plans for an indictment.

TITLE: Putin makes a surprise visit to Mariupol and tours an occupied city destroyed by war
SUMMARY: The trip was Putin's first-ever visit to the Donbas region, which Russia illegally annexed last year. It followed the International Criminal Court's decision to issue a warrant for him on war crimes.

TITLE: California enters a contract to make its own affordable insulin
SUMMARY: Under the $50 million deal, the state is partnering with drugmaker Civica to start making the new generic insulin later this year, Gov. Gavin Newsom said.

TITLE: A nuclear power plant leaked contaminated water in Minnesota. Here's what we know
SUMMARY: The 400,000 gallon leak of water containing tritium occurred in November 2022, but the general public was not notified until last week. Officials said the leak is contained and poses no public danger.

TITLE: A new Arkansas law allows an anti-abortion monument at the state Capitol
SUMMARY: Arkansas Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders has signed a law to allow a monument near the state Capitol marking the number of abortions performed in Arkansas before <em>Roe v. Wade

TITLE: UBS to buy troubled Credit Suisse in deal brokered by Swiss government
SUMMARY: UBS will buy rival Credit Suisse for more than $2 billion in a deal brokered by Swiss officials to try and prevent a banking crisis.

TITLE: Gloria Dea, the 1st magician to perform on the Las Vegas Strip, dies at 100
SUMMARY: Dea was the first magician to perform on what would become the Las Vegas Strip in the early 1940s. She also appeared in several movies in the 1940s and '50s.

TITLE: The body of a teenager found dead near the Murdaugh estate in 2015 will be exhumed
SUMMARY: Stephen Smith's death was ruled a hit-and-run. His body was found 15 miles from the estate of former South Carolina attorney Alex Murdaugh, who was found guilty this month of killing his wife and son.

TITLE: China's Xi Jinping flexes his diplomatic muscle with a visit to Moscow
SUMMARY: Analysts say China's role as a mediator in the past suggests limits to what it may achieve when it comes to Ukraine.

TITLE: Miami Beach sets curfew to control spring break crowds after 2 shootings
SUMMARY: The city issued a 11:59 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew starting Sunday night in an effort to curb violence after two fatal shootings took place over the weekend.

TITLE: New York Community Bank agrees to buy a large portion of Signature Bank
SUMMARY: The 40 branches of Signature Bank will become Flagstar Bank, starting Monday. Flagstar is one of New York Community Bank's subsidiaries.

TITLE: Millions of dead fish have been found in an Australian river due to low oxygen levels
SUMMARY: Millions of dead fish have been found dead in an Australian river due to dangerously low oxygen levels in the water caused by receding flood waters, government officials said.

TITLE: Big names including Steve Buscemi, Conan O'Brien come out to honor Adam Sandler
SUMMARY: Ben Stiller, Jennifer Aniston and Chris Rock were also among the comedians in Washington, D.C. this weekend to celebrate Sandler, who worked on Saturday Night Live in the 1990s and moved on to films.

TITLE: Emmanuel Macron faces no-confidence votes as pressure builds from pension protests
SUMMARY: Since becoming president in 2017, Emmanuel Macron often has been accused of being out of touch. But government officials are hoping to survive a no-confidence vote because the opposition is divided.

TITLE: The start of the Iraq War 20 years later in photos
SUMMARY: On March 20, 2003, the U.S. carried out its first airstrikes in Iraq.

TITLE: The number of Black video game developers is small, but strong
SUMMARY: We talk to five people who are forging their own path in the industry, and bringing their unique experience to the world of video games.

TITLE: Colorectal cancer is rising among Gen X, Y & Z. Here are 5 ways to protect yourself
SUMMARY: If you are in you're in  your  20s, 30s and 40s, you need to know the signs to watch for and when to seek screening or treatment for colorectal cancer.

TITLE: Got a question for Twitter's press team? The answer will be a poop emoji
SUMMARY: Twitter's communications email went dark after mass layoffs late last year. CEO Elon Musk announced this weekend (and NPR confirmed) that it now responds to press inquiries with a single poop emoji.

TITLE: In 'The Teachers,' passion motivates, even as conditions grow worse for educators
SUMMARY: Alexandra Robbins illuminates how teachers, who shape our future, live a constant battle against financial pressure, entitled parents, politicians, and the educational system at the local level.

TITLE: Cut emissions quickly to save lives, scientists warn in a new U.N. report
SUMMARY: Cutting greenhouse gas emissions rapidly and immediately will save lives, livelihoods and ecosystems around the world, scientists say. And there are lots of ways to go about it.

TITLE: Latest on Ukraine: Xi Jinping visits Moscow to meet Putin (March 20)
SUMMARY: Catch up on key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: France's leaders fight 2 no-confidence motions as the pension backlash rages on
SUMMARY: The motions were filed by lawmakers angry with President Macron for forcing through an unpopular bill raising the retirement age from 62 to 64. It's been 60 years since a no-confidence motion passed.

TITLE: Giant African snails, a voracious invader, are intercepted at Detroit's airport
SUMMARY: Considered one of the most damaging snails in the world, the U.S. has worked spent over a $1 million over decades to eradicate them.

TITLE: House GOP demands testimony and documents from New York prosecutor investigating Trump
SUMMARY: House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and other top Republicans argue DA Alvin Bragg's probe is politically motivated and won't stand up in court. Donald Trump looms over a Republican retreat in Florida.

TITLE: A jury convicts 3 men of the robbery and murder of rapper XXXTentacion
SUMMARY: Michael Boatwright, 28, Dedrick Williams, 26, and Trayvon Newsome, 24, were all found guilty and will receive mandatory life sentences at a later date.

TITLE: U.S. aid worker and French journalist freed after years in captivity in West Africa
SUMMARY: Jeff Woodke, an American missionary and humanitarian aid worker, was kidnapped by militants in 2016. Olivier Dubois, who was a correspondent for French news outlets, was kidnapped in 2021.

TITLE: As many as 18 million Americans may soon lose coverage and not realize it
SUMMARY: A federal rule that prevents states from dropping people from Medicaid rolls during the pandemic expires at the end of March.

TITLE: First Republic Bank shares sink to another record low, but stock markets are calmer
SUMMARY: Shares in the midsized lender continued to tumble as fears grow about First Republic's financial health grow even after it received a $30 billion lifeline from its bigger rivals last week.

TITLE: What France's revolt over raising the retirement age says about the attitude to work
SUMMARY: France is in turmoil over President Emmanuel Macron's move to raise the retirement age from 62 to 64. New polling shows a huge majority of the population disagrees with how it was done.

TITLE: The Supreme Court wrestles with questions over the Navajo Nation's water rights
SUMMARY: Almost a third of the reservation's 170,000 residents lack access to clean, reliable drinking water. The tribe wants to be able to represent itself in litigation over the Colorado River.

TITLE: Fox News seeks to silence one of its own over $1.6 billion defamation lawsuit
SUMMARY: The network says it had to seek a restraining order against producer Abby Grossberg after she threatened to reveal what it calls "privileged information" in a case brought by Dominion Voting Systems.

TITLE: The potentially deadly Candida auris fungus is spreading quickly in the U.S.
SUMMARY: Cases of the fungus in which it did not respond to antifungal medicine tripled in 2021. It can be deadly, but does not seem to have adverse effects on healthy people.

TITLE: Japan's prime minister arrives in Ukraine for talks with President Zelenskyy
SUMMARY: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida began a surprise visit to Ukraine early Tuesday, hours after Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in neighboring Russia for a three-day visit.

TITLE: Can moderates survive state politics? In Montana, they may be going extinct
SUMMARY: Across the country, parties are consolidating political power in states and squeezing out the moderate middle. In Montana, that squeeze is changing political representation and whose voice counts.

TITLE: Before the U.S. rolled into Baghdad 20 years ago, Iraqis warned us what would happen
SUMMARY: When the U.S. invasion of Iraq began, NPR's Mideast editor Larry Kaplow was a reporter in Baghdad. Looking back now, he writes that the signs and warnings of the chaos to come were all too clear then.

TITLE: A 90-year-old tortoise named Mr. Pickles just became a father of 3. It's a big 'dill'
SUMMARY: It's significant, according to officials with the Houston Zoo, because the radiated tortoise is a critically endangered species whose numbers are in decline.

TITLE: What Trump's 'arrest' claim says about his hold on politics and the 2024 election
SUMMARY: Donald Trump claimed on social media that he will be arrested on Tuesday and called for mass protest. His unfounded claims showed his continued influence on the Republican Party.

TITLE: Unions in Los Angeles begin 3-day school strike

TITLE: Medicaid renewals are starting. Those who don't reenroll could get kicked off
SUMMARY: With a pandemic-era rule expiring this month, people on Medicaid will have to re-qualify to keep their coverage.  Language barriers, housing instability and computer literacy could stand in their way.

SUMMARY: Twenty years after the invasion of Iraq, the U.S. Senate is moving to repeal the congressional authorization that provided the justification for the war.

SUMMARY: The U.S. invasion of Iraq 20 years ago gripped the entire nation. Today it is far from the minds of most Americans, though not for the veterans who served there.

SUMMARY: The 2023 men's tournament is wide open: to find a recent champion in the Sweet 16 field, you have to go all the way back to 2014 winners UConn.

SUMMARY: The veterinary tranquilizer has been linked to a growing number of overdose deaths across the country, especially in the Northeast. It's often combined with fentanyl, but can't be treated with Narcan.

SUMMARY: A trio of lawsuits allege that JP Morgan Chase and Deutsche Bank actively enabled Jeffrey Epstein to run a sex-trafficking ring for underage girls. A judge partially denied a motion to dismiss.

SUMMARY: <em>Poverty, by America

SUMMARY: The Treasury Secretary said the administration is committed to protecting the U.S. banking system and customers who trust their money to it.

TITLE: Could the banking turmoil affect you? 5 ways it might
SUMMARY: There are possible consequences for regular people, small businesses and the economy.

TITLE: Demonstrations, protests mark first day of LA school strike
SUMMARY: Support staff in the nation's second-largest school district walked out over stalled contract negotiations. Teachers joined them in support.

SUMMARY: As speculation mounts that Donald Trump could soon be indicted over hush money payments, Alvin Bragg may have to make a history-making decision.

SUMMARY: The boss of the hit video-sharing app will deliver remarks to lawmakers in Washington on Thursday in an attempt to assuage growing fears about the app's connections to China.

SUMMARY: Two dolphins were discovered on the shore in Sandy Hook Bay in New Jersey last week. By Tuesday, rescuers had discovered eight stranded dolphins in total.

SUMMARY: Children's book author Carole Lindstrom follows her Caldecott-winning picture book We Are Water Protectors with another celebration of Native culture in My Powerful Hair

SUMMARY: China's Xi Jinping says he has a peace plan for Ukraine and wants to mediate an end to the war. Ukraine and its neighbors are skeptical.

TITLE: After Greece's worst train crash, young Greeks rally for change ahead of elections
SUMMARY: Young people throughout Greece have staged large protests following last month's collision near the city of Larissa, which killed 57 people, many of them students.

SUMMARY: For Passover, many Jews clean their homes and cars. The New York attorney general's office said there are reports of car washes raising their prices 50% for Jewish customers ahead of Passover.

SUMMARY: Limited national data suggest teachers are plentiful, but many districts that serve some of the most vulnerable students would beg to differ.

SUMMARY: Across the U.S. on Tuesday, people gathered outside major banks demanding that financial institutions shift away from investing in fossil fuel projects.

SUMMARY: The boss of the hit video-sharing app will deliver remarks to lawmakers in Washington on Thursday in an attempt to assuage growing fears about the app's connections to China.

SUMMARY: In 1626, a father and son sat for a portrait. Nearly 400 years later their story is still being examined by experts in Europe.

TITLE: Uh-oh. A new tropical mosquito has come to Florida. The buzz it's creating isn't good
SUMMARY: Little is known about the mosquito species known as Culex lactator. But it belongs to a group of mosquitoes known to carry diseases and researchers are worried about what will happen.

TITLE: Garbology is the study of trash. This is why students love it

SUMMARY: Ever since frontman Win Butler was accused of sexual misconduct by several people in 2022, Arcade Fire's hometown scene has struggled with how to respond.

SUMMARY: Uganda's parliament has passed sweeping new anti-LGBTQ+ laws with tougher punishments, making some acts punishable by death.

SUMMARY: The strongest tornado to impact the Los Angeles metro area in 40 years touched down at 11:14 a.m. for two to three minutes, according to the National Weather Service.

SUMMARY: The Chevrolet Camaro, for decades the dream car of many teenage American males, is going out of production early next year. But General Motors says another generation may be in the works.

SUMMARY: The World Clown Association is bringing together all types of clowns for its 40th annual convention.

TITLE: A wolverine has been seen outside of its normal range for the first time in 30 years

SUMMARY: Passports are in "unprecedented demand," U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said. In 2022, the State Department issued a record 22 million passports â and 2023 is on track to break that record.

SUMMARY: The man who inspired the novel and the Hollywood film <em>Hotel Rwanda

TITLE: Distraction, speeding and alcohol contribute to a 16-year high in traffic deaths
SUMMARY: The 2021 numbers from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration confirmed earlier estimates showing a 10.5% increase in deaths over 2020. The 43,000 deaths were the highest total since 2005.

TITLE: Prosecuting an ex-U.S. president is not common. What about in other democracies?
SUMMARY: So what does it say about America that Donald Trump is the first former U.S. president to be indicted? NPR's Steve Inskeep asks political science professor James D. Long.

TITLE: Actor Leonardo DiCaprio testifies in Fugees' Pras Michel conspiracy trial
SUMMARY: Prosecutors allege Pras Michel illegally helped steer money from a Malaysian billionaire who helped finance<em> The Wolf of Wall Street

TITLE: Trump has arrived in New York for his arraignment. What's next?
SUMMARY: The former president will spend Monday night at Trump Tower before his surrender and arraignment on Tuesday, when the historic charges against him will be unsealed.

TITLE: The Nashville school shooter planned the attack for 'months,' police say
SUMMARY: The Metro Nashville Police Department released new findings on Monday about Audrey Hale, the assailant who fatally shot six people at an elementary school in Nashville last week.

TITLE: Other countries have prosecuted their leaders. What took the U.S. so long?
SUMMARY: Other democracies, from Europe to South America to the Middle East, have prosecuted their current or former leaders. Why did the U.S. wait so long to take that step? A political scientist weighs in.

TITLE: The father of the cellphone predicts we'll have devices embedded in our skin next
SUMMARY: Martin Cooper made the first-ever cellphone call exactly 50 years ago. He says artificial intelligence is the new frontier.

TITLE: More storms and tornadoes have been forecast for the Midwest and South
SUMMARY: More dangerous weather is expected in the same communities that lost more than 30 people from tornadoes just days ago.

TITLE: Twitter users say they haven't paid for their blue checks but still have them
SUMMARY: The social media company said it would start removing blue checks from accounts that haven't signed up for its paid service, Twitter Blue. With one exception, it's unclear if it's taken any action.

TITLE: A second autopsy has been done in a probe of an unsolved South Carolina death

TITLE: The UConn Huskies beat San Diego State to claim its 5th men's basketball championship
SUMMARY: The University of Connecticut Huskies defeated the San Diego State Aztecs 76-59 Monday night to claim the school's fifth men's college basketball title.

TITLE: An ex-aide to Maryland's former governor is dead after a manhunt, lawyer says
SUMMARY: A former Maryland political aide wanted on corruption charges died Monday after he was wounded while being confronted by law enforcement agents, his lawyer said, following a manhunt.

TITLE: Australia bans TikTok from federal government devices
SUMMARY: Australia is the last of the "Five Eyes" security partners â the U.S., Canada, Britain and New Zealand â to ban the Chinese-owned video-sharing app TikTok from its federal government's devices.

TITLE: Hit animated film 'Moana' will receive a live-action remake, Disney announced
SUMMARY: Auli'I Cravalho and Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, who voiced Moana and Maui, respectively, in the 2016 film, will reprise their roles in the live-action version, Disney said.

TITLE: The Dogecoin price spikes after Elon Musk changes Twitter logo to the Shiba Inu dog
SUMMARY: Elon Musk is currently facing a $258 million class action federal lawsuit accusing him of engaging in a pyramid scheme for voicing his support for Dogecoin in several tweets.

TITLE: Recovery high schools help kids heal from an addiction and build a future
SUMMARY: A few dozen high schools across the U.S. combine education with treatment for substance use disorders to keep kids in recovery â and in school.

TITLE: Business slowly comes back to Venezuela's border after re-friending Colombia
SUMMARY: Cross-border trade between Colombia and Venezuela has slowly opened up after the countries reengaged following years of bad relations.

TITLE: Today's election could weaken conservatives' long-held advantage in Wisconsin
SUMMARY: It's the final day to vote in Wisconsin's Supreme Court race that's broken national spending records. The winner could be the swing vote on issues like abortion, redistricting and election lawsuits.

TITLE: There are plenty of doomsday climate stories â 'Extrapolations' is about the everyday
SUMMARY: "We wanted to focus on what we call the 'messy middle...' " says Scott Burns, creator of the AppleTV+ series. "Before we get to the end, there's a lot of life that we're all gonna have to go through."

SUMMARY: The former president and 2024 hopeful has been indicted by a grand jury, multiple sources close to Trump confirmed to NPR. Join NPR as we unpack key moments.

SUMMARY: Anthony Chin-Quee captures the space between medicine's all-consuming demands and its practitioners' fallibility in a cautionary tale of his own mental and physical struggles as a Black physician.

TITLE: Venezuela slowly starts to see perks of renewed ties with Colombia
SUMMARY: Cross-border trade between Colombia and Venezuela has slowly opened up after the countries reengaged following years of bad relations.

SUMMARY: It's not clear whether the former president will have a mug shot taken when he appears in a Manhattan court on Tuesday. And even if he does, a state mug shot law may prevent the public from seeing it.

SUMMARY: Cross-border trade between Colombia and Venezuela has slowly opened up after the countries reengaged following years of bad relations.

TITLE: Sunisa 'Suni' Lee says she's stepping away from gymnastics due to a kidney issue
SUMMARY: The Auburn University sophomore and Olympic gold medalist said she was dealing with a "non-gymnastics health related issue" involving her kidneys but didn't rule out a bid for the 2024 Paris Olympics.

SUMMARY: Democratic state officials say they're ready to dispense thousands of mifepristone doses if access to the pill becomes difficult as a result of a pending federal lawsuit.

SUMMARY: The former president has arrived at the criminal court to turn himself in for arraignment.

SUMMARY: His death last month at a Virginia mental hospital has sparked outrage and led to second-degree murder charges against 10 defendants.

SUMMARY: Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg has announced a 34-count felony indictment of former President Donald Trump. Read the criminal charges here.
